Award.AwardTitle: White Dwarf Mergers as Progenitors of Type Ia Supernovae
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a detailed theoretical study of the mergers of dead solar-type stars. Such mergers have recently been proposed as an important channel for the production of supernovae explosions of the Ia type, which are the most important probes of the expansion of the universe over cosmic time. The research will use the CASTRO hydrodynamics code, and will model what happens when two white dwarfs come into contact during the merger process. The simulations will include a nuclear reaction network to determine whether it is possible for an explosion to take place at the time of the merger. The mergers will be modeled in the orbital (corotating) reference frame will minimize the numerical error, maintaining angular momentum conservation throughout coalescence. The simulation approach will be validated through rigorous testing that will demonstrate the ability of the algorithm to maintain stable Newtonian orbits.

The award will also support the training of students and early-career scientists in computational astrophysics. Codes from this project will be widely distributed to the community. The project is also expected to have a scientific impact by improving the understanding of supernova progenitors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF award AST-1211563, White Dwarf Mergers as Progenitors of
Type Ia Supernovae, funded research into producing one class of bright stellar
explosions know as type Ia supernovae. While these events are
observed frequently and serve as "standard candles," objects
of known brightness used as distance indicators, a theoretical
understanding of these events remains elusive. This study
addressed the question of whether or not one proposed progenitor system,
the merger of two white dwarf stars, could be the setting of
these supernovae. The results of the study suggest that
while more study is needed, white dwarf mergers are a viable
setting for type Ia supernova explosions.

The approach taken by the collaboration was to perform full
three-dimensional simulations in order to explore and
characterize the merger process.  Accordingly, much of the effort
went in to adapting a community code, CASTRO, code to perform these
simulations. Modules were developed to efficiently solve the
equations describing the dynamics of the merging stars,
including nuclear reactions and the ability to perform
simulations in a reference frame co-rotating with the stars
for higher accuracy. A module was also developed to describe
the gravitational waves emanating from these events, and
such signals may some day be observed by gravitational wave
observatories.

The collaboration for the award consisted of faculty and
students at Stony Brook University working with collaborators
at other institutions. The award offered a great opportunity for
training students in computational science, including both
graduate and undergraduate students. The award funded the
dissertation research of one graduate student who has now
graduated, and the study continues with another student's
dissertation. Undergraduate students participated in the
visualization and analysis of the results and thereby
gained valuable experience. Thus a broader impact of this
award was the training of students that will allow them to
to be the computational scientists of tomorrow.

The software developed for this study allowed simulations with
unprecedented realism, and the source code has been made
freely available to the astrophysics community. One of the
broader impacts of this study is that research into
this and other related problems will thus continue using the tools
developed with resources from this award.

Publications resulting from this award:

"White Dwarf Mergers on Adaptive Meshes. I. Methodology and Code
Verification," Katz, M. P., Zingale, M., Calder, A. C., Swesty, F. D.,
Almgren, A. S., and Zhang, W. 2016 ApJ, 891, 94

"pyro: A teaching code for computational astrophysical hydrodynamics." 
Zingale, M. 2014 Astronomy and Computing 6  p. 52.

"On the Piecewise Parabolic Method for Compressible Flow with Stellar
Equations of State, Zingale, M. and Katz, M. P. 2015 ApJ 216 2

Meeting the Challenges of Modeling Astrophysical Thermonuclear Explosions:
Castro, Maestro, and the AMReX Astrophysics Suite Zingale, M.; Almgren,
A. S.; Barrios Sazo, M. G.; Beckner, V. E.; Bell, J. B.; Friesen, B.;
Jacobs, A. M.; Katz, M. P.; Malone, C. M.; Nonaka, A. J.; Willcox, D. E.;
Zhang, W.  Proceedings of AstroNum 2017, Journal of Physics Conference
Series, in press.

Results from this study were also presented in 18 talks or posters by the investigators and students.
